hint: Create a clear, single-sentence summary of your story's core idea.
title: The Logline
subtitle: Your story in a nutshell.
description: A single sentence that summarizes your story, its protagonist, their objective, and the central conflict. A great logline is both a selling tool and a narrative compass.

hint: What is the single thing your audience must remember?
title: The Takeaway
subtitle: The one thing they'll never forget.
description: Identify the one key message you want your audience to walk away with. Craft your entire story around reinforcing this single idea.

hint: What's the big idea your story supports?
title: The Central Theme
subtitle: The universal truth at the heart of your tale.
description: Explore the universal concept or truth that underpins your narrative. It could be love, betrayal, redemption, or the struggle for power. This gives your story depth and resonance.

hint: Identify the core problem you're trying to solve.
title: The Why
subtitle: The problem that demands a solution.
description: Define the central problem or challenge that your story addresses. This 'why' gives your narrative purpose and provides a clear motivation for the actions that follow.

hint: What's the main obstacle to success?
title: The Conflict
subtitle: The struggle that drives the plot.
description: Introduce the main struggle that your characters must face. Without conflict, there is no story. This can be internal, external, or a combination of both.

hint: What's the one thing that will change everything?
title: The Inciting Incident
subtitle: The moment that sets the story in motion.
description: Pinpoint the event that thrusts the protagonist into the main action of the story. This is the catalyst that changes their ordinary world.

hint: Frame your story around a clear, simple moral.
title: The Moral of the Story
subtitle: The lesson to be learned.
description: Create a story that illustrates a clear moral principle. This is a powerful way to make your message resonate and be easily remembered.

hint: Distill your story into a short, attention-grabbing pitch.
title: The Elevator Pitch
subtitle: The ultimate quick sell.
description: Condense your entire story into a pitch that can be delivered in 30 seconds or less. This forces you to focus on the most compelling elements.

hint: What question does your story pose to the audience?
title: The Central Question
subtitle: The hook that keeps them listening.
description: Pose a question at the beginning of your story that the audience needs answered. This creates curiosity and keeps them engaged until the very end.

hint: Think of a story you love and identify its core components.
title: Reverse Engineer a Story
subtitle: Deconstruct to build your own.
description: Choose a story that moves you and break it down into its constituent parts: protagonist, conflict, theme, plot points. This reveals the mechanics behind effective storytelling.

hint: Ask 'what if' to generate a crazy idea.
title: The 'What If' Generator
subtitle: Unleash your imagination.
description: Begin your brainstorming with a simple, provocative question: What if... This can lead to unexpected and compelling story premises that you wouldn't have considered otherwise.

hint: Create a timeline of key events and see what story emerges.
title: The Story Timeline
subtitle: Map out the moments.
description: Visualize your story by plotting key events on a timeline. This helps you identify the rhythm and pacing of your narrative, ensuring a logical progression.

hint: What are the common stories told in your industry?
title: Story Archetypes
subtitle: Borrow from the past.
description: Identify and analyze classic story patterns or 'archetypes' relevant to your field. These patterns are instantly recognizable to audiences and provide a powerful framework.

hint: Find the human truth behind the data.
title: Data to Narrative
subtitle: From numbers to feelings.
description: Translate abstract data and statistics into a personal, human story. Find the 'person' or 'people' behind the numbers to make your findings relatable and impactful.

hint: Talk to people to discover their true motivations.
title: The Deep Interview
subtitle: Listen for the hidden story.
description: Ask open-ended questions to uncover the personal narratives and emotional truths of a subject. The real story often lies beneath the surface of official statements.

hint: Imagine your ideal audience member.
title: Audience Persona
subtitle: Know who you're talking to.
description: Create a detailed profile of your target audience. Knowing their values, fears, and aspirations helps you tailor your story to resonate deeply with them.

hint: Combine two unrelated ideas to create something new.
title: Story Fusion
subtitle: Mix and match.
description: Take two completely different concepts, genres, or stories and combine them. The tension and novelty of this combination can spark a fresh, original narrative.

hint: Go out into the world and find an unexpected detail.
title: Sensory Details
subtitle: The sights, sounds, and smells of a story.
description: Pay close attention to your surroundings and note specific sensory details. Weave these into your story to make it feel more vivid, authentic, and immersive.

hint: What do people say when theyâ€™re not trying to impress you?
title: The Anecdote
subtitle: The short, human story.
description: Find a short, personal, and true story that illustrates a point. Anecdotes are highly relatable and can make complex ideas feel approachable.

hint: Create a character who grows and changes.
title: The Protagonist
subtitle: The hero of the story.
description: Create a central character who undergoes a significant transformation. Their journey of overcoming internal and external challenges is the core of your narrative.

hint: Give your character a single, simple desire.
title: The Want
subtitle: What your character desperately needs.
description: Equip your protagonist with a clear and compelling desire. This is the driving force behind their actions and a powerful source of audience connection.

hint: Who or what is standing in their way?
title: The Antagonist
subtitle: The force of opposition.
description: Introduce an opposing force that challenges your protagonist. This antagonist, whether a person or an idea, creates the necessary conflict to propel the story forward.

hint: What makes them relatable?
title: The Flaw
subtitle: The imperfection that makes them human.
description: Give your character a significant flaw or weakness. This makes them more relatable and makes their eventual triumph more meaningful and earned.

hint: What's the one thing they'll never tell anyone?
title: The Secret
subtitle: A hidden truth that changes everything.
description: Give your character a secret that, if revealed, would completely alter the story. This creates tension, mystery, and a strong character motivation.

hint: Create a foil to your main character.
title: The Supporting Cast
subtitle: The people who help or hinder the journey.
description: Build out the characters who support or challenge your protagonist. These characters provide valuable context and highlight different facets of the main character's personality.

hint: Build a character around a specific personality trait.
title: The Archetype
subtitle: A universal character model.
description: Utilize classic character types that are instantly recognizable to your audience (e.g., the mentor, the trickster, the rebel). This provides a quick and powerful foundation.

hint: How do they interact with their world?
title: The Behavior
subtitle: Show, don't just tell.
description: Instead of telling your audience what your character is like, show it through their actions, mannerisms, and how they react to events. This makes them feel real.

hint: Give them a backstory that shapes their choices.
title: The Origin Story
subtitle: Where they came from.
description: Explain how your character became who they are. Their past experiences, successes, and failures inform their present actions and make their journey more believable.

hint: What's their role in the story?
title: The Sidekick
subtitle: The faithful companion.
description: Create a character who supports the protagonist's journey. They can provide comic relief, a different perspective, or simply be a loyal ally.

hint: Make your story a clear call to action.
title: The Call to Action
subtitle: What do you want your audience to do?
description: End your story with a clear, concise instruction. Tell your audience exactly what steps to take next. This turns a narrative into a powerful persuasive tool.

hint: Tell a story to justify a new decision.
title: The Justification Story
subtitle: Explaining the 'why' behind the what.
description: Use a story to explain and defend a decision or change. By showing the journey to the decision, you can build trust and make the rationale clear.

hint: Use a story to bring a team together.
title: The Unifying Narrative
subtitle: A story that creates a shared vision.
description: Craft a story that defines a team's or company's mission and purpose. It provides a common goal and a shared sense of identity that can inspire and align everyone.

hint: Use a story to sell a product or idea.
title: The Sales Narrative
subtitle: The pitch that connects with emotion.
description: Instead of just listing features, tell a story about how your product or idea solves a problem and transforms a life. This builds an emotional connection.

hint: Use a story to teach a lesson or a skill.
title: The Teaching Tale
subtitle: Learning through narrative.
description: Embed a lesson or a how-to guide within a narrative. Stories are a natural way for the brain to process and retain information, making learning effortless.

hint: What story does your brand tell?
title: The Brand Story
subtitle: The essence of your identity.
description: Create a narrative that defines your brand's values, mission, and personality. It's the story you want your audience to tell about you.

hint: Tell a story to explain why you're a good fit.
title: The Personal Brand Story
subtitle: Your story is your advantage.
description: Use a personal anecdote to illustrate your skills, values, and experiences. This is often more effective than simply listing accomplishments on a resume.

hint: Use a story to explain a complex topic.
title: The Explanatory Narrative
subtitle: Making complexity simple.
description: Break down a complex system or idea by turning it into a story with a beginning, middle, and end. This makes abstract concepts relatable and easy to follow.

hint: Begin with the outcome and work backward.
title: The Reverse Chronology
subtitle: Start at the end and explain how you got there.
description: Begin your story with the final result or conclusion, then rewind and explain the sequence of events that led to that moment. This is a great way to build suspense.

hint: A simple problem, a simple solution.
title: The Pitch Structure
subtitle: A five-point plan for a clear message.
description: Follow this simple structure: 1. Introduce the hero. 2. Define the problem. 3. Propose the solution. 4. Explain the plan. 5. Show the happy ending.

hint: Set up a question, answer it, and then move on.
title: Question and Answer
subtitle: A natural way to guide a narrative.
description: Structure your story as a series of questions and answers. Each question you pose builds anticipation, and each answer provides a satisfying moment of clarity.

hint: The most common and satisfying structure.
title: The Three-Act Structure
subtitle: Setup, Confrontation, and Resolution.
description: Divide your story into three parts. The first act introduces the world and the conflict. The second is about overcoming challenges. The third resolves the conflict and concludes the narrative.

hint: What's the one thing that will change everything?
title: The Twist
subtitle: The surprise that recontextualizes the past.
description: Introduce a shocking revelation at a critical point in the story that forces the audience to rethink everything they thought they knew. This can be a powerful emotional climax.

hint: Use a framework to present a process.
title: The Process Story
subtitle: A step-by-step journey.
description: Frame a process or workflow as a story. This makes it easier to understand, remember, and follow, as it has a clear beginning, middle, and end.

hint: Compare two seemingly unrelated things.
title: The Analogy
subtitle: Making the unfamiliar familiar.
description: Explain a complex or abstract idea by comparing it to something simple and well-known. This provides an instant shortcut to understanding.

hint: Use simple, powerful, and evocative language.
title: The Rule of Three
subtitle: Small numbers are memorable.
description: Present ideas in sets of three. This creates a rhythm that is pleasing to the ear and makes the information easier to recall and internalize.

hint: Use visual language to make your story more vivid.
title: Show, Don't Tell
subtitle: Draw a picture with words.
description: Instead of telling your audience what's happening, use descriptive language to show it. This engages their imagination and makes the experience more immersive.

hint: Find the voice that best fits your story.
title: The Voice
subtitle: The personality behind the words.
description: Determine the tone and style of your narrative. Is it formal or casual, serious or humorous? A consistent voice helps your story feel authentic.

hint: Keep your sentences short and impactful.
title: The Short Sentence
subtitle: Power in brevity.
description: Use short sentences to create a sense of urgency, highlight a key point, or provide a dramatic pause. This stylistic choice adds rhythm and impact to your writing.

hint: What makes your story feel unique?
title: The Tone
subtitle: The mood and feeling of your narrative.
description: Establish the overall mood of your story. The tone can be serious, whimsical, suspenseful, or nostalgic. It shapes how your audience feels as they engage with your narrative.

hint: Introduce an element that will pay off later.
title: The Chekhov's Gun
subtitle: Every element must have a purpose.
description: A narrative principle that states that every element in a story must be necessary. If you introduce an object or detail, it must be relevant later in the story.

hint: What's the goal?
title: The Objective
subtitle: What are you trying to achieve?
description: Before you begin, define the clear objective of your story. This provides a clear destination and ensures every part of the narrative works towards a single purpose.

hint: Tell your story in three parts.
title: The Three-Point Plan
subtitle: Start, middle, and end.
description: Every story needs a beginning, a middle, and an end. The beginning introduces the world, the middle explores the conflict, and the end resolves it. Simple, effective, and universal.

hint: Cut out everything that isn't essential.
title: The Red Pen
subtitle: Simplicity is the soul of effectiveness.
description: Review your story and ruthlessly remove any unnecessary details, characters, or scenes. A concise story is a powerful one.

hint: Find the core message and filter the rest.
title: The Filter
subtitle: Focus on what matters.
description: Identify the core message of your story and use it as a filter. If a scene, character, or detail doesn't support that message, it doesn't belong.

hint: A simple, memorable structure for presentations.
title: The Pyramid Principle
subtitle: Start with the conclusion.
description: Begin with your main point or conclusion, then support it with three key arguments. Each argument can then be supported by its own set of details.

hint: Map your story to a circular path.
title: The Hero's Journey
subtitle: The cycle of transformation.
description: A classic story structure where a hero leaves their ordinary world, faces challenges, achieves victory, and returns transformed. This provides a satisfying and complete narrative arc.

hint: Break down a complex process into a simple story.
title: The Process Map
subtitle: From start to finish.
description: Turn a complex workflow into a story by defining a clear beginning, middle, and end. This makes the process easy to understand and remember.

hint: What's the one thing they'll never tell anyone?
title: The Story Spine
subtitle: A quick outline for a full story.
description: A powerful tool for quickly outlining a story: 'Once upon a time... Until one day... And because of that... Until finally...' This ensures a logical flow.

hint: Re-order your story for maximum impact.
title: The Shuffle
subtitle: Find a new perspective.
description: If your story isn't working, try rearranging the order of your scenes or plot points. A new sequence can reveal a fresh perspective or create a different emotional journey for the audience.

hint: Start your story with the action.
title: In Medias Res
subtitle: Beginning in the middle of things.
description: Start your story in the middle of a pivotal moment. This immediately grabs the audience's attention and creates a desire for context and backstory.

hint: How do you want your story to end?
title: The Ending
subtitle: The final destination.
description: Determine your conclusion before you write. Knowing where you're going makes it easier to craft a clear and impactful narrative that leads to a satisfying final point.

hint: Bring your team's purpose to life.
title: The Brand Story
subtitle: The emotional core of your company.
description: Tell a compelling narrative about your brand's origins, values, and purpose. This is a powerful way to connect with your audience on a deeper level.
